title: Tyson Fury to bank £11.9m from WWE debut match against Braun Strowman
text:
Fury fights Strowman at the end of this month (Picture: Getty)

Tyson Fury will reportedly pocket just under £12million for his WWE match against Braun Strowman this month.

The heavyweight boxer is set to make his debut in the world of wrestling on 31 October, taking on his new arch enemy Strowman after repeatedly confronting the WWE star.

Fury made two guest appearances on WWE before announcing his fight with Strowman, causing a mass brawl last week on Raw.

While the boxing world has been shocked by Fury’s surprise stint in the WWE, the Daily Mail claim it will be a lucrative adventure for the Gypsy King.

Braun Strowman didn't take too kindly to Tyson Fury's knockout threat 😯🤣🖊️pic.twitter.com/JTjQydll20 — Metro Sport (@Metro_Sport) October 15, 2019

Fury will bank £11.9m ($15m) for his clash with Strowman, which will be staged in Saudi Arabia.

As Anthony Joshua did when he announced his rematch with Andy Ruiz Jr in Saudi Arabia, Fury has faced a wave of criticism for travelling to a country with serious human rights issues.

Fury brushed aside concerns about fighting in Saudi Arabia, saying: ‘I’m not a politician. I’m a fighting man from a fighting gypsy family and I go where I’m paid to fight.’

Deontay Wilder is sure to keep one eye on Fury’s match with Strowman, with the Bronze Bomber scheduled to rematch his rival on 22 February.

Fury is recovering from two bad cuts (Picture: AP)

Frank Warren has already said he would prefer Fury did not fight Strowman amid his recovery from two nasty cuts and the Brit admitted he could not guarantee he wouldn’t get injured.

‘People say that WWE is a fake but now I know the hard reality. It’s the most physically taxing sport I’ve ever been involved in,’ Fury said.

‘My first days of training opened my eyes to how athletic these guys really are. There’s always going to be injuries in a contact sport but I’m not worried.

Fury pockets big money from his WWE debut (Picture: Getty)

‘I’m a born prize-fighter who’s been fighting his whole life.’

‘I’ve been training at the WWE facility in Orlando,’ he continued.

‘I was supposed to be resting while the eye mended but I’m excited about 385lbs of Braun coming at me.

‘Yeah, me against Wilder is the biggest fight in boxing but I’m not thinking about that now. I’m just enjoying my life – and concentrating on WWE.’
